Sanding pad vibrates in a randomly changing circular motion.
Belt rotates around two pulleys; sander is moved while wood is held stationary.
Work is secured and drill moved by hand.
Can be used to drive screw with special bits.
The blade reciprocates up and down, cutting on the up stroke.
The blade reciprocates in and out, cutting on the in stroke.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
Wood is moved on table into blade.
Wood is moved on table into blade.
The blade reciprocates up and down, cutting on the down stroke.
Wood is moved across tabletop either against fence or pushed with miter gauge: NEVER CUT FREEHAND.
Blade slides forward on rail, cutting on the pull stroke.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
Slides forward above wood.
Swings down in chopping motion.
Slides back on rails, cutting on the push stroke.
Rail assembly can be locked so that saw can only chop like a standard miter saw.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
Blade swings down in chopping motion.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
The jointer is used to true the edges of boards that is make them very straight at a constant angle to the face.
The wood is pushed on the table along the fence and into the spinning knives.
Planer is used make the faces of a board flat and parallel.
The wood is fed between the spinning roller/knife assembly and the table.
The lathe is used to “turn” or cut rectangular pieces into cylindrical forms.
The wood is mounted between the spindles and spun, while turning chisels are used to cut the cylindrical profiles.
The shaper or router is used to “mold” the edges of boards, that is shape them into specific molding profiles.
The wood is pushed on the table along the fence or with the miter gauge and into the spinning knives.
Uses different bits for many different grinding purposes.
Use for finish sanding on wood, plastic, foam, etc..
Used only to fasten wood together.
Used only to fasten wood together.
Rough sands and shapes.
The spindle spins (and on some models oscillate up and down) while the wood is moved against the tabletop.
Use down draft table for any sanding, routing, or grinding.
Drill bit is mounted in a chuck, which travels up and down on the quill.
Drills holes perpendicular to table.
Bores a squared hole.
The router is used to cut slots and dados, and to mould the edges of boards.
The wood is secured and the router is moved by hand.
Use both hands to hold the sander firmly. Always be able to hold against the direction of belt rotation.
Secure the wood. The sander will try to throw loose wood.
Never approach from attacking angle. Do not tear the belt on sharp corners.
Be aware of belt tracking and tension. Shut off machine and alert shop personnel if belt tracks wrong, especially if sparks are created.
Do not use if belt is loose or torn. Alert shop personnel.
Keep hands away from abrasive surfaces, especially near intake gaps.
Do not sand electrical cord, loose clothing and/ or cloth in the sanding area.
Keep electrical cord free of snags.
Do not drill “blind”. Do not drill without ascertaining backside of work is clear of obstructions.
Do not drill into tabletop or support.
Do not abuse electrical cord.
Keep electrical cord free of snags.
Use both hands on drill. If the bit binds up, the drill will try to wrench itself violently from your grip, so be prepared.
Do not drill “blind”. Do not drill without ascertaining backside of work is clear of obstructions.
Do not drill into tabletop or support.
Do not abuse electrical cord.
Keep electrical cord free of snags.
Make sure blade extends completely through material throughout stroke.
Secure material before cutting. Small and/or thin material may flex or vibrate causing loss of control.
Do not drill “blind”. Do not drill without ascertaining backside of work is clear of obstructions.
Do not drill into tabletop or support.
Do not abuse electrical cord.
Keep electrical cord free of snags.
Make sure blade extends completely through material and beyond shoe throughout stroke.
Secure material before cutting. Small and/or thin material may flex or vibrate causing loss of control.
USE ONLY UNDER DIRECT SUPERVISION OF SHOP PERSONNEL.
Set blade depth so that the teeth emerge completely from underside of cut.
Keep the blade aligned along straight path. Make sure you don’t bind the blade.
Never cut “blind.” Always ascertain that underside of cut is clear of obstructions.
Do not cut into tabletop or supports.
Make sure both sides of the cut are supported even after the cut is made.
Do not cut electrical cord.
Allow blade to stop spinning before placing saw down after cut is finished.
Take extreme care when making bevel cuts, as the angle between the blade and foot can bind the blade easily.
Always hold saw with both hands.
Secure small and/or thin work with clamps. The wood must not be allowed to move during the cut.

Wood must flat against table and stable. Never cut round or unstable wood without secondary support (such as a jig). The downward force of the blade will twist round or unstable stock as it cuts, causing the blade to bind, kink, and break.
Set guard 0.25" above wood.
Never force a curved cut tighter than allowed by the blade width.
Watch your fingers, especially at the end of the cut.
Never back out of long cuts with the machine running. Backward pressure can cause the blade to jump its guides, hang up, and break.
Plan your cuts before you begin cutting. Make sure the wood will clear the throat throughout the cut. Make release cuts before cutting long curves.

Wood must flat against table and stable. Never cut round or unstable wood without secondary support (such as a jig). The downward force of the blade will twist round or unstable stock as it cuts, causing the blade to bind, kink, and break.
Set guard 0.125" above wood.
Never force a curved cut tighter than allowed by the blade width.
Watch your fingers, especially at the end of the cut.
Never back out of long cuts with the machine running. Backward pressure can cause the blade to jump its guides, hang up, and break.
Plan your cuts before you begin cutting. Make sure the wood will clear the throat throughout the cut. Make release cuts before cutting long curves.
Watch your fingers.
Make sure blade has teeth pointing down.
Make sure tension is adjusted properly on the blade.
Do not push too hard on wood. You want only enough pressure to maintain good contact on the down stroke, not the up stroke.
Do not use without specific permission, specific training, and direct supervision.
Firmly fix wood against table and fence: never cut freehand.
Hold wood with left hand, cut with saw in right hand.
Slow steady feed: hold backpressure on saw: DO NOT TRY TO CUT TOO QUICKLY.
Always check for square.
Tilted blade bevel cuts are most prone to binding and thus most dangerous.
Always return saw to its full rear position after the cut.
Never “gang cut.” Never cut more than one piece at a time.
Avoid cutting deeper than a 16th of an inch into the tabletop.
Firmly fix wood against table and fence: never cut freehand.
Hold wood with left hand, cut with saw in right hand.
Slow steady feed: DO NOT TRY TO CUT TOO QUICKLY.
Always check for square.
Tilted blade bevel cuts are most prone to binding and thus most dangerous.
Always return saw to its full rear position after the cut.
Never “gang cut.” Never cut more than one piece at a time.
Firmly fix wood against table and fence: never cut freehand.
Hold wood with left hand, cut with saw in right hand.
Slow steady feed: DO NOT TRY TO CUT TOO QUICKLY.
Always check for square.
Tilted blade bevel cuts are most prone to binding and thus most dangerous.
Always return saw to its full rear position after the cut.
Never “gang cut.” Never cut more than one piece at a time.
Must have had proper instructions on how to use the jointer.
Shop personnel must supervise you when using it.
Use push blocks and push sticks to feed wood through cutters.
Be aware of where your fingers and hands are placed when using the jointer.
Keep in feed and out feed table clean and clear of debris.
Must have had proper instructions on how to use the thickness planer.
Shop personnel must supervise you when using it.
Wood must be free of all dirt or any metal and paint.
Must wear face shields, dust mask, and ear protection when using the machine.
Remove only a maximum of a 16th of an inch at a time.
Do not use without specific permission, training, and direct supervision.
Do not use without specific permission, training, and direct supervision.
Safety glasses, dust mask, and ear protection are required for use of the tool.
Be aware of body parts near grinding bits.
Be aware of loose clothing and material.
Item in which you are grinding must be properly clamped or held down.
Always wear dust mask.
Don’t sand treated wood with lead paints.
Avoid damaging sanding pad.
Five inch pneumatic sander with dust collector.
Always wear eye protection.
Keep all body parts a safe distance away from the area of nailing.
NEVER POINT THE NAIL GUN IN THE DIRECTION OF OTHERS.
Avoid nailing in areas of knots, metal, and/or other hard areas in the wood.
Always have nailer pointed against the wood when nailing.
Always wear eye protection.
Keep all body parts a safe distance away from the area of nailing while in use.
NEVER POINT THE NAIL GUN IN THE DIRECTION OF OTHERS.
Avoid nailing in areas of knots, metal, and/or other hard areas in the wood.
Always have nailer pointed against the wood when nailing.
Hold wood firmly, always be able to hold against the direction of sander.
Never approach from attacking angle.
Be aware of belt tracking and tension. Shut off machine and alert shop personnel if belt tracks wrong, especially if sparks are created.
Do not use if belt or disk is loose or torn. Alert shop personnel.
Keep hands away from abrasive surfaces, especially near intake gaps.
Use tables to support material when sanding against a vertical belt or disk.
Hold wood securely. Loose wood will be thrown violently.
Do no stand in line with out feed of belt. Do not let others stand in line of the out feed.
Never sand pieces too small to hold safely.
Never use gloves or a rag to hold material.
Use sanding disk on down side, not up side.
Sand with the grain whenever possible.
Keep work moving. Do not over sand in one place.
Keep material flat against the tabletop.
Use light pressure. Do not burn out the sandpaper.
Wear dust mask when sanding on table.
Do not lean over table when using push button cleaning.
Do not use table as a workbench.
Use only bits appropriate for the material.
Make sure that the bit tight and straight in chuck.
Remove key from chuck before turning on.
Secure wood, clamping it whenever possible.
Do not drill into metal table.
Place a scrap of wood under work to avoid tear-out.
Check drill speed: faster for soft materials or small bits, slower for hard material or large bits. Adjust speed only with drill on.
Never use auger bits in the drill press.
Avoid awkward hand positions in which a sudden slip would cause hand to go into the cutting tool.
Hold work in left hand and operate drill with right hand.
Never wear gloves, neckties, jewelry, loose clothing, or long loose hair.
Secure wood in vise.
Use the proper chisel/ bit combination.
Tighten bit and remove chuck.
Do not over work chisel and bit.
Do not mortise your hand.
Do not use without specific permission, specific training, and direct supervision.

Blade elevation.
Fence settings.
Use the proper bit for the proper material.
Variable speed.
Uses 5 hole, hook and loop sand paper.
Nails vary from 5/8 of an inch to 2.5 inches.
Nails vary from 2 inches to 3.25 inches.
Belt swivels from horizontal to vertical. DO NOT CHANGE WITHOUT PERMISSION OF SHOP PERSONNEL.
tables tilt 0\-45 degrees.
Miter gauge can be used.
Some models have interchangeable spindles of various diameter.

Mobile wheels.
110-volt receptacle.
Add solid tabletop to use as a workbench.

Uses different sizes of chisels from 1\/4” – 1”.

Various guides, jigs, templates, straight edges, and accessories for specific procedures.
Half Sheet Finish Sander: uses a half sheet of sandpaper.
Quarter Sheet Palm Sander: uses a quarter sheet of sandpaper.
Palm Sander: round pad.
Small, hand held belt.
Hand-held drill.
Hand-held, with a short stout blade extending from bottom (foot).
Hand-held, with a stout blade extending from end.
Hand-held circular blade.
Long, continuous band blade looped around large upper and lower wheels
Long, continuous band blade looped around large upper and lower wheels.
A short thin blade held through the table by a long arm.
Circular blade mounted into table.
Circular blade mounted on overhead rail (arm).
Circular blade mounted on a double action arm.
Circular blade mounted on single action arm.
A series of short knives mounted on a horizontal spindle set into a long flat table equipped with a fence.
A series of 15 inch knives mounted on a horizontal spindle set above a short table and equipped with self-feeding rollers.
two spindles equipped with a parallel tool rest
A series of short knives mounted on a vertical spindle set into a short flat table equipped with a fence and miter gauge.
Or a Router mounted upside-down in a table with a fence.
Hand-held rotary grinder.
Five inch pneumatic sander with dust collector.
Pneumatic 18 or 16 gage.
Pneumatic chip nailer.
Combination: belt and disk sander.
A cylindrical sanding spindle mounted in a table.
Self-contained dust collection unit.
Overhead drill mounted above adjustable table.
Hollow square chisel with a drill bit in the center built in a press.
Essentially a smaller, hand held, inverted version of the wood shaper.
Straight or curved cuts in moderately thin wood (up to length of blade).
Freehand rough cuts (up to length of blade).
Straight cuts.
Rips-cuts and crosscuts on stock too large to fit on table saw, radial arm saw, or miter saw.
Straight cuts and wide curves.
Versatile: rip-cuts, crosscuts, miters, re-saws, and long radius curves in medium size boards and panels.
It cuts any size piece of wood that will fit through throat and on table.
Curves are cut freehand.
Rip-cuts are cut with fence.
Crosscuts and miters are cut with miter gauge.
Straight cuts and wide curves.
Versatile: rip-cuts, crosscuts, miters, and long radius curves.
Curves and rip-cuts are cut freehand.
Cuts any size piece of wood that will fit through throat and on table.
Crosscuts and miters are cut with miter gauge.
Intricate and delicate curves in flat, thin wood.
Straight cuts Rip cuts (along board’s length) with fence.
Cross- cuts on panels with panel attachment.
Cross-cuts and miter cuts on short boards with miter gauge.
Dado and mill work with fence.
Straight cuts.
Crosscuts and compound miters in long boards and narrow panels.
Crosscut dados and rabbets.
Straight cuts.
Compound crosscuts and miter cuts in long boards.
Crosscut and miters in long narrow boards.
Compound Miter Saw cuts compound miters in long narrow boards.
Clips must be pulled back and proper nail size must be placed in with heads up.
Clips must be pulled back and proper nail size must be placed in with heads up.

All of the same precautions taken with the large stationary sanders also apply to the smaller hand sanders, especially the hand belt sander. The finishing and random orbit sanders, however, produce far less force and are thus generally safer. Always wear a dust mask when sanding, especially when there is not a dust collector on the machine. NEVER SAND WOOD PAINTED WITH LEAD-BASED PAINT IN THE DESIGN SHOP. Special hazardous materials precautions must be taken with the dust produced from sanding lead-based paint. If you cannot determine with absolute certainty that a paint is not lead-based, treat it as if it were.
All hand sanders are equipped with trigger locks that lock the sander in the on position. Make sure the lock is off before plugging in the sander.
Some hand sanders are equipped with dust collecting bags. Always check these bags before and after use, and empty any dust inside.

Although straight blade saws such as the band saw are somewhat safer than circular saws, misuse can still result in serious bodily injury. Band saws are generally more versatile than circular saws, and they are able to make many of the same kinds of cuts as well as others. Unlike circular saws, cuts on band saws can be made free hand (without fence or miter gauge) as long as the pieces are given adequate and stable support throughout the cut. This means that curved cuts can be made as well as straight. However, the band saw does not cut as precisely as a circular saw and cannot cut dados and rabbets.

Special care must be taken with tools that cut with a circular blade. These blades cut with tremendous forces, and the radial motion of the blades can both throw wood and debris outward and pull fingers and loose clothing inward. The wood being cut must be held securely at all times. If allowed, the blade will try to move the wood violently rather than cutting it.
NEVER CUT FREEHAND WITH MOUNTED CIRCULAR SAWS NEVER PLACE HANDS CLOSER THAN 6” TO A MOVING BLADE.

Besides the general cutting and sanding tools, there are many other tools used for specialized shaping, such as jointing edges, planning surfaces, and cutting molding. For the most part, these power-shaping tools are some variation of a cutter blade (composed of knives or blades mounted on a spindle or shaft) and a guide surface or surfaces. Such tools include the jointer, the planer, the wood shaper, and the router. With the lathe, the wood is spun on spindles and the cutting instruments (the chisels or turning knives) are held stationary. Hand shaping is performed with a variety of chisels, knives, rasps and files, as well as small all-purpose devices such as the Dremel and rotary cutter. The safety procedures for the shaping tools are essentially the same as those for the circular saws. Keep in mind, however, that the knives on the shaper cutters are generally much larger than the teeth of the saw blades and there for are more prone to grab loose clothing and throw large splinters.

Pneumatic tools are powered using compressed air and must be connected to the shop’s air supply. Compressed air lines are throughout the shop at most work -stations in the form of hoses. Air hoses use a female fitting that will connect to the male fitting on the tools. Before use of the tool, the tool should be oiled with proper air tool oil.

The large stationary sanders are used primarily for shaping and coarse sanding. These sanders remove material very quickly and must be used very carefully. Deep gouges can be quickly cut into the wood surface, and edges can easily be sanded crooked. Always hold the piece securely, and sand with light, even pressure, moving the piece constantly. Use the tables and guides whenever a straight or beveled edge is required and use of such aids is possible. Trying to sand too quickly will result in poor accuracy and sloppy work. The primary danger of power sanders is that the users underestimate their hazard because there are no blades. They can however be just as dangerous as saws. The hazards of power sanders include (1) the radial forces of the spinning parts, (2) the abrading power or the sanding surfaces, and (3) the fine particles of dust created. Power sanders have been known to pull out hair by the roots and tear flesh away to the knuckles. Wood dust can be extremely flammable, and the dust created from sanding lead-based paints and other materials can pose long term health risks to both the operator and others in the area. Let me reiterate:
NEVER LEAVE SANDERS RUNNING UNATTENDED.
ALWAYS MAINTAIN SECURE FOOTING AROUND THE SANDER.
NEVER WEAR GLOVES, LOOSE CLOTHING, JEWELRY, NECKTIES, OR LONG LOOSE HAIR NEAR SANDERS.
NEVER LEAN OVER OR REACH UNDER RUNNING SANDERS.
NEVER POWER SAND METALS, INCLUDING NAILS, SCREWS, OR OTHER FASTENERS IN THE WOOD. Sparks can ignite air borne sawdust. Countersink fasteners below wood surface before sanding.
NEVER POWER SAND PAINTED WOOD OR OTHER MATERIALS IN THE DESIGN SHOP.
ALWAYS RUN DUST COLLECTOR WHEN SANDING.

The principle danger of power drill is the loss of control by the operator and the danger of loose material being twisted up onto the bit. Remember, the bit is spinning, creating the hazards of radial forces.
See all drill bit types.

Router bits are essentially a smaller version of the wood shaper cutters. They come in a variety of shapes and profiles, each suited for a particular kind of cut. There are two types of router bits (1) plunge and (2) bearing. Plunge bits are used to cut in the center area of a board, whereas a bearing bit cuts around the edges.
See all router bit types.
A small, all-purpose shaping device for very detailed work. It is similar in configuration to a router without a guide base, and can be utilized for shaping, sanding, grinding, and much more.
See all dremel bit types.

Similar to the hand drill, but battery powered and used primarily for driving screws. Cordless drills are often equipped with a clutch that slips when the screw is seated, preventing the head from being broken off or stripped out. Phillips head and square head screws work best.
See all drill bit types.
Countersink: creates an enlarged hole with an angled bottom to allow screw heads to set below the surface.
Combination Bit: a flat tapered bit with a shoulder for drilling and countersinking holes for wood screws.
Forstner Bit: a very precise bit for cutting large holes over 0.5 inch.
Bullet Point Bit: a woodcutting bit with a “bullet” point that reduces point drift and cuts a hole with a flat bottom (also called a Brad-point bit).
Reduced Shank Twist Bit: a large twin-fluted bit with a smaller shaft.
Twist Bit: a twin fluted bit with a beveled point appropriate for general drilling in wood or metal.
Spade Bit: a flat, inexpensive bit for boring large holes over 0.5 inch wide. Not accurate and tend to tear-out the beginning and ends of cuts.
Auger: drills large deep holes with a brace or slow speed hand drill. The threaded point screws into the wood and pulls the bit deeper. IT CANNOT BE USED IN THE DRILL PRESS.
Fly Cutter: an adjustable hole saw. IT CANNOT BE USED WITH A HAND DRILL, AND CAN ONLY BE USED IN THE DRILL PRESS.
Hole Saws: for sawing large holes (1 to 3 inches) through wood no thicker than twice its length (3-0.5 inches max).
[Plunge Bits]Straight: creates an enlarged hole with an angled bottom to allow screw heads to set below the surface.
[Plunge Bits]Round nose: a flat tapered bit with a shoulder for drilling and countersinking holes for wood screws.
[Plunge Bits]Dovetail: a very precise bit for cutting large holes over 0.5 inch.
[Plunge Bits]V-groove: cuts V shape grooves.
[Bearing Bits]Molding: cuts a molding profile.
[Bearing Bits]Chamfer: cuts a sloped corner.
[A-E]High speed rotary cutters: for general purpose shaping of wood, metal, or plastics.
[F-H]Tungsten carbide cutters: longer lasting cutters.
[I]Wire brush: for cleaning corrosion and rust on metals.
[J-M]Grinding points: for grinding metal.
[N]Cutting disks and Mandrel:
A: Phillips Bit
B: Slotted Bit
C: Square Recess
D: Socket Hex Head
E: Star
F: Star Insert
G: POZIDRIV
H: Hand Drive Adapter for socket wrenches.
